abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the National Response to
            HIV/AIDS Project for Zambia were as follows: outcomes were
            satisfactory, the risk to development outcome was moderate,
            Bank performance was satisfactory, and Borrower performance
            was also satisfactory. Some lessons learned included:
            despite the progress achieved, prevention of new HIV
            infections at community level is still a challenge and
            should receive priority for the next generation of
            subprojects. Communities should be encouraged to improve
            their understanding of the dynamics of a generalized
            epidemic and the remedies needed to address it. Reducing the
            incidence of HIV and AIDS is the ultimate goal and measure
            of success in the fight against HIV and AIDS. This goal
            should be on the radar screen of everyone involved in HIV
            and AIDS work. However, the successful community
            mobilization did not match with an effective referral system
            to health facilities. Although the impact of the community
            response was not built in the design, there are plans to
            measure the effectiveness of the response with support from
            the Bank and Department for International Development
            (DFID). Mainstreaming HIV and AIDS in line ministries took
            the form of a standard menu of interventions. Interaction
            between ministries was enhanced through the planning
            meetings. This opened avenues for sharing information and
            lessons learnt in implementation of work place activities.
            However, line ministries still need to work on external
            mainstreaming and there is also an urgent need to strengthen
            work place programs within the private sector especially
            small business. Retention of trained youth volunteers at
            youth friendly health centers is still a challenge. There is
            a high turnover among youths running community youth
            projects. Outreach activities where youth interacted with
            adult health staff were less acceptable and less likely to
            succeed than those where interaction was among youths
            themselves. However, designated youth centers in places
            where privacy and easy access was assured were more likely
            to succeed than those established in crowded clinical settings.
